article.description: Robert Tomaszek collected season highs of 28 points and 15 rebounds as No. 25 Texas Tech survived a rough end to regulation in a 99-89 overtime victory over Minnesota

images.name: Knight Bob 021228 inline
images.caption: Bob Knight gave Minnesota crowd a show and his team an earful.

related.description: Bob Knight coached in a Big Ten arena Saturday and the result was predictable: a loss for the home team.
related.linkText: Shelman: Just like old times for Knight
related.title: Just like old times for Knight in Big Ten territory
related.headline: Just like old times for Knight in Big Ten territory

article.headline: Knight makes winning return to Big Ten court
article.linkText: Knight triumphs with Tech in return to Big Ten
article.story: MINNEAPOLIS (AP) -- In the midst of a furious Minnesota rally that would send the game into overtime, Texas Tech coach Bob Knight wasn't worried about keeping what had been an 11-point lead. "I told them, 'Get it into overtime, because we'll play better,' '' Knight said. He was right. The Red Raiders (No. 25 ESPN/USA Today) scored on every possession in overtime except for the last, outscoring the Gophers 25-15 en route to a 99-89 overtime win Saturday. Robert Tomaszek scored a career-high 26 points and grabbed 16 rebounds and Knight got career victory No. 795 as Texas Tech (8-1) weathered a furious second-half charge by Minnesota (6-3). "Twenty-five points in five minutes is unacceptable,'' Minnesota coach Dan Monson said. Andre Emmett added 24 points and Kasib Powell had 16 points, eight rebounds and six assists for Texas Tech. Moe Hargrow scored a career-high 24 points and Rick Rickert had 22 points and 11 rebounds to lead the Gophers. The game appeared to be over with Texas Tech up 10 points with 2:15 to play in regulation. But Steve Esselink's 3-pointer started a 12-2 Gophers run that sent the game into overtime. Hargrow's layup cut the lead to three with 1:13 left and Rickert's 3-pointer tied the game at 74 with 32.4 seconds to play. "We were within 2:15 of playing 40 good minutes,'' Knight said. "To lose a lead, go into overtime and come back and win the game, that's a real credit to those kids.'' Tomaszek's production was key considering that Emmett, coming off back-to-back 31-point games against New Mexico and New Mexico State, sat out most of the first half with foul trouble. "A huge point for us was the way we played without Emmett in there for a lot of the first half,'' Knight said. "A lot of our offensive game revolves around Emmett. For us to be up seven at halftime, that was the whole difference for us.'' Tomaszek scored 14 points in the first half, including eight in the final 2:40 to give Texas Tech a 37-30 halftime lead. "Tomaszek had his way with us in there,'' Monson said. "I don't think there's any question Tomaszek was the one who beat us today.'' It was Knight's first appearance in a Big Ten arena since being fired from Indiana in 2000 for what the university called a "pattern of unacceptable behavior.'' After being booed by a season-high crowd of 14,156 at Williams Arena, Knight watched his Red Raiders shoot 56.7 percent from the field and force 20 turnovers. But the Polish-born Tomaszek was the difference. "I just played my role, got the rebounds and got the garbage work, did the dirty work,'' Tomaszek said. "That's what they recruited me for.'' Texas Tech had an answer for every Minnesota rally, scoring almost at will throughout the second half and overtime. "I've never seen a defense break down progressively through a game like that,'' Monson said. After sitting with foul trouble in the first half, Emmett scored 17 points in the second half and overtime. "We had to suck it up,'' Emmett said. "We started to play well (in overtime). We just regrouped and executed on offense and were intense on defense.''
